The Hollow Hold is a full-body isometric exercise, primarily working your core (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, obliques) to stabilize the spine by preventing arching, while also engaging hip flexors, quads, lower back muscles (erector spinae, quadratus lumborum), shoulders (deltoids, pecs), and neck muscles to maintain the static, "hollow" shape against gravity, teaching core tension and spinal bracing for other movements. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Core (Primary): Rectus Abdominis, Transverse Abdominis, Obliques. 
• Legs: Quadriceps, Hip Flexors (to keep legs lifted and straight). 
• Back: Erector Spinae, Quadratus Lumborum (to press lower back down). 
• Shoulders/Chest: Deltoids, Pectorals (to keep arms overhead). 
• Neck: Muscles stabilizing the head. [1, 2, 3, 4]  

Movement Pattern 

• Type: Isometric Anti-Extension. 
• Action: Your core muscles contract to resist extension (arching) of the lower back, creating a rigid, braced posture. 
• Goal: To maintain a "hollow" shape where the lower back is pressed flat to the floor, ribs down, with limbs extended away from the body, challenging your entire anterior chain. [2, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

How it Works 
You hold a static position, preventing movement, forcing deep core muscles to work hard to keep your spine stable and protect it from gravity's pull, building essential bracing skills for exercises like squats, deadlifts, and handstands. [2, 5, 6, 8]
